title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. This account is considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Act allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution, unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The amendments made by paragraph (1) regarding demand deposit accounts will take effect two years after the date of enactment of this Act. Authorization of interest-bearing transaction accounts. Repeal of prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits and joint rulemaking required for authorization of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. The Federal Reserve Act, Home Owners' Loan Act, and Federal Deposit Insurance Act are amended or repealed to allow for the payment of interest. The Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies are required to issue joint final regulations within 2 years to establish the scope of the authorization. Federal banking agencies will issue joint final regulations allowing the payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. The regulations will define the scope of authorization, types of accounts included, and any limitations or restrictions. The regulations must be effective within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. Definitions for "depository institution" and "transaction account" are provided. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Definitions for "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency" are provided. The repeal's effective date is within 2 years of the Act's enactment or when final regulations under subsection (b) become effective. SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The Board may issue regulations on the payment and distribution of these earnings to the institutions. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The distribution of earnings to depository institutions and their responsibilities, including trust companies and corporations, is outlined. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions, including trust companies and corporations, to earn interest on balances held at a Federal Reserve bank. Amendments also include authorizing pass-through reserves for member banks and making technical and conforming changes to the Act. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to remove certain subparagraphs and make technical changes. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements and to address the treatment of certain escrow accounts. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to address the treatment of escrow accounts used for real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments. These activities include absorbing expenses, forbearing from charging fees, and providing benefits to the account holder.
